channel.title: Art & Photography – SUBCULTURED Magazine
channel.description: A fashion, culture, art and music publication, written by students about students.

item.title: Catch-up With A Creative: RoseSol Designs
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
As seen on Instagram, Rosesol’s handmade zip scrunchies and satin headscarves combine simplicity and ingenuity for big statement accessories.    Solene, 21-years-old and recently graduated from Leeds, started out making custom pieces for her friends from recycled clothes, matching accessories for nights out and eye catching ensembles for summer festivals. Now, less than a year on, […]

The post Catch-up With A Creative: RoseSol Designs appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
As seen on Instagram, Rosesol’s handmade zip scrunchies and satin headscarves combine simplicity and ingenuity for big statement accessories.   

Solene, 21-years-old and recently graduated from Leeds, started out making custom pieces for her friends from recycled clothes, matching accessories for nights out and eye catching ensembles for summer festivals. Now, less than a year on, she has over 1000 followers on Instagram and has recently been offered a space on ASOS Marketplace.

View this post on Instagram

The neon zip scrunchie thanks to this amazing team for incorporating my work… Art direction @sjun.ashfordb photography @minori.jpg model @drissiakpk bag @justharrydesigns ring @girlwithpearls._ styling @orlamaireadmcmullan (added a 0.6% pink hue to fit theme) x dream team £7.50 free UK postage message to buy

A post shared by Rose Sol Designs (@rosesoldesigns) on Feb 8, 2020 at 8:58am PST

Could you tell me a little about how you got started?

It was something that I wanted to do for ages and ages. The year before I had made tops for me and my friend for festivals in the summer. I made one bralet out of a recycled rucksack for my friend and she got loads of compliments on it, so it got me thinking. But I didn’t actually think anyone would buy anything from me, I didn’t really have the confidence to do it…

However, when I was working as a stylist for the Leeds RAG Fashion show, we used lots of my own tops that I made by hand and one of my lovely models said to me “I don’t understand why you don’t have a page or Instagram, because people would buy this !” and she said “when you go home literally make the account tonight!”… so I did . At the start I only posted to show people what I had made and I didn’t expect anyone to buy anything. 

Who are your style biggest inspirations?

I usually use Instagram and Pinterest, I don’t really follow ‘fashion’ that closely I kind of just do my own little thing and take inspiration from the things I see people wear. 

What small businesses are you buying from at the moment?

@earrings.by.anna for dainty handmade earrings
@justharrydesigns for sustainable and ethical denim 
@girlwithpearlsjewelry for fun hair pieces 
@slowgarments for eco-conscious swimwear 

What has surprised you about starting RoseSol Designs?

I think how nice and supportive people have been, not even my friends but girls I don’t know who have shared, commented or interacted on my page, which is great because it really boosts your interactions. It is crazy I have shipped everywhere across the UK, Australia and America, which I find mad how people in different countries want to buy things I have made. I’ve even had girls coming back for their 9th or 10th scrunchie which makes you feel really good when people want what you make, but also come back for more and promote you!

View this post on Instagram

matching mask AND scrunchie … I’m living lol pandemic but try and make it fashion ? (we have to raise the mood somehow) I’ve added a filter pocket to each mask so you can insert your own filters for extra protection! Any material can be used & choice of orange, blue or pink elastic #uk #independentartist #etsy #depop #ukdesigner #handmade #fashion #ukblogger

A post shared by Rose Sol Designs (@rosesoldesigns) on Apr 7, 2020 at 5:53am PDT

Do you have any big plans for the future?

The next step… well I have just secured my ASOS Marketplace agreement to have a shop on there, so I will see how that goes for the first few months. I do really want to set up my own website but I don’t really have the technical skills for that *if anyone wants to help please holllaaa*. I have visions of people being able to select their material and customise their items, so they can see what it looks like, alongside a gallery so people wearing my designs can upload photos etc.,  but maybe I’m dreaming hahah…

Follow RoseSol Design on Instagram at @rosesoldesign.

Text by Eve Willis.

The post Catch-up With A Creative: RoseSol Designs appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: El Raval, Barcelona’s Beating Heart
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Barcelona’s spirited barrio located on the periphery of the gothic quarter is infamous for its seedy reputation. Yet, it is home to a unique brand of multiculturalism that bears witness to the unlikely convergence of diversity and the encroaching gentrification, catalysed by a tourist boom that challenges the community core of many European cities.   Nearly half of the neighbourhood’s residents (48%) are immigrants born outside of Spain, […]

The post El Raval, Barcelona’s Beating Heart appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Barcelona’s spirited barrio located on the periphery of the gothic quarter is infamous for its seedy reputation. Yet, it is home to a unique brand of multiculturalism that bears witness to the unlikely convergence of diversity and the encroaching gentrification, catalysed by a tourist boom that challenges the community core of many European cities.  

Nearly half of the neighbourhood’s residents (48%) are immigrants born outside of Spain, of this number, 22% are of Pakistani origin. Dubbed less amicably by Barceloneses as Ravalistan, it is not impossible to see why when at a fleeting glance the abundance ofmosques, men dressed in the traditional shalwar kameez and constricted streets with dilapidated shutters, could be mistaken for those of Kabul.

Yet, coexisting in the city’s most densely populated zone is the seamless amalgamation of identities.  Filipinos, Eastern Europeans, Bangladeshis and Latinos, both newly arrived and second generation, students that opt for this barrio for it’s cheap rent, central location and proximity to nocturnal frivolities. Spanish migrants, from all far corners of the country, choosing the barrio precisely for the same reason that many born in Raval decide to leave, its vivacity. Meanwhile, a sizable proportion of old timer Catalans remain, some who have observed their homes through civil war anarchism, Franco fascism, hardship and now affronting the new war of gentrification.  

To understand why El Raval still endures a mala fama, or notoriety for its salubrious activities, its origins must be understood. El Raval began as an unwanted overflow from the ancient gothic nucleus and emblematic La Rambla. Named Rabad, quickly castellenised to El Raval, the arab word for outskirts was synonymous with prostitution, deprivation and debauchery, home to what the city itself did not want. Informally it became known as the Barri Xinès (China Town), for its established position as the underworld of Barcelona, where the shameless pursuit of every hedonistic vice was possible.

The neighbourhood has encountered and been at the forefront of the cities most pivotal historical events, fringing the old port and gothic centre, it has been a crucible of immigration, the first industrialised centre of Spain and a political hotbed of activism for socialism and anarchism. Since Post Franco rejuvenation began in the 1980’s, of the Rambla de Raval, the MACBA and the CCBB, the safety and reputation of the area has improved substantially. However, as it becomes trendier tourism becomes one of the biggest social challenges for the residents, who are fighting to retain their neighbourhood, as the tourism economy overspills.

Today take a walk in the winding labyrinth of streets, you will see the bubbling creativity and character emerging, constituted by the colourful convergence and patchwork of immigrants from across the globe, with each respective nationality represented by Asian food supermarkets, ethnic restaurants or Pakistani barbers. Look deeper you with stumble across independent book shops, Erasmus students studying in hipster coffee joints, Catalan independentista flags flying proudly, skater cool kids outside the MACBA drinking Estrella Damn cans, vegan menu del dia restaurants and always a shifty character in a graffiti lined doorway a reminder of the darker side of the barrio.

Juxtaposed by the constant stream of temporary tourists, whose presence weaves momentarily  through the living neighbourhood, in the form of farcical bicycle tours on the Rambla de Raval, happy snappers, new expensive hotel chains and boisterous bar hoppers chasing cheap copas on Joaquín Costa. Although these impermanent visitors are capable of sucking the soul out of the city, Raval remains indignant and the tourists and locals become a daily paradox, that adds an additional layer to its fabric.

However, It can not be denied that El Raval comes with a level of gritty realism, that extends further than locals warning you to keep an eye on your bag, continually making the headlines for violence, the epidemic of narcopisos occupationsand prostitution. In addition, El Raval has absorbed a huge consequence of the tourist industry, with over 40% of the cities Illegal tourist flats located in Raval, which have polarised opinion as they are thought to underpin gentrification of the barrio by pricing locals out, dissolving the community with money made pouring out to foreign owners and provoking narcopisos, as unattended flats make its very easy for drug gangs to squat in and bring violence into the heart of the community,

However, for all of its problems El Raval can be forgiven, it is where you will find not only the worst of the city, but the best too. Initiatives and creative projects that have formed in the neighbourhood stand as a testament to the strength of the community and resolute determination to retain its unique homogenous character. One example is Raval Safari, that is free monthly walking tour led by an artist with the intention of rebuking the neighbourhoods negative stereotype, or photographers such as Marouane Joubba, Moroccan photographer based in Barcelona who uses the medium of photos to highlight the diversity and colour of the barrio.

If you have plans to travel to Barcelona this year check this travel advice to stay up to date for your journey.

Text by Eve Willis
Featured image by @fotoraval.

The post El Raval, Barcelona’s Beating Heart appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Five Woke Musicals You Need To See
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Seeking Christmas gift inspiration ? Or simply searching for a winter pick-me-up? Look no further and get inspired with our five must-see empowering musicals. 2019 has been a momentous year for many reasons, both good and bad! Yet despite all the negative political noise, we have seen unprecedented progress for marginalised groups across the globe. […]

The post Five Woke Musicals You Need To See appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Seeking Christmas gift inspiration ? Or simply searching for a winter pick-me-up? Look no further and get inspired with our five must-see empowering musicals.

2019 has been a momentous year for many reasons, both good and bad! Yet despite all the negative political noise, we have seen unprecedented progress for marginalised groups across the globe. Celebrate the year for its spirit of self-acceptance and strength in adversity, by indulging in an uplifting evening, packed with feel-good catchy bops and heart-warming story lines.

 & Juliet

This new musical is a modern take on the Shakespearean classic Romeo and Juliet, which attempts to rewrite its tragic finale with the help of some of the biggest songs from the past two decades. ‘&Juliet’ chronicles Juliet’s journey of self-discovery after Romeo, as she realises that her life is only just beginning after his ends. A powerful reminder to women, that as Juliet discovers, life existed before, and will continue after a man. Tickets are available now to watch ‘&Juliet’ at the Shaftesbury Theatre, London.

Everybody’s Talking About Jamie

Inspired by a true story, ‘Everybody’s Talking about Jamie’ is a touching tale about 16-year-old teen who does not fit in. With the help of his mum and close friends, Jamie overcomes the ostracization of society and learns the beauty of self-acceptance, pursuing his dream of becoming a drag queen. The hit musical has been nominated for five Olivier awards and has won three ‘WhatsOnStage’ awards including ‘Best New Musical’, which is no surprise as it so wonderfully captures the struggle with identity that many young people can relate to today. See ‘Everybody’s Talking about Jamie’ now at the Apollo Theatre, London.

Tina

As a tribute to the life of soul sensation Tina Turner, it showcases the adversities she faced during her lifetime, before becoming one of the best-selling artists of all time. From a troubled childhood, to surviving sexual abuse and racism in the music industry, this musical is a testament to the strength of all African-American women of Tina’s generation, who refused to be silenced. See ‘Tina’ at the Aldwych Theatre in London where it is playing until July 2020.

Six

‘Six’ is a contemporary twist on the lives of Henry VIII’s six wives, who reclaim their stories and refuse to have their lives defined by one man. An absolute must watch for women everywhere, this fast paced, feel-good musical demonstrates the importance of women supporting one another. Aside from the girl-power, the pop-concert style musical is full of catchy songs that you won’t be able to forget. Due to its popularity, the show’s residence at the Arts Theatre in London has been extended to July 2020, not bad for its humble beginnings at the Edinburgh Fringe festival.

Waitress

After opening on Broadway in 2016, the musical sensation ‘Waitress’ has travelled over to London and has won over critics and audiences alike. Its protagonist Jenna, is a waitress stuck in an abusive marriage, with little hope of realising her future dreams. When an opportunity for happiness presents itself in a new town, Jenna must find the courage and confidence to escape the shackles of her relationship and put herself first. This story of female empowerment is enough to encourage anyone to stand up against their oppressor. Tickets are available now for ‘Waitress’, which is playing at the Adelphi Theatre, London until March 2020.

Text by Daisy Colley
Photos from Pinterest.

The post Five Woke Musicals You Need To See appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Sorry, boomers – but given that it will be the younger generations who will bear the brunt of a post-Brexit Britain shouldn’t we be listening to them? Three years have passed since the 2016 referendum, and Britain is more divided than ever. MPs remain locked in a bitter stalemate over negotiations with the EU, the […]

The post The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Sorry, boomers – but given that it will be the younger generations who will bear the brunt of a post-Brexit Britain shouldn’t we be listening to them?

Three years have passed since the 2016 referendum, and Britain is more divided than ever. MPs remain locked in a bitter stalemate over negotiations with the EU, the rift between Brexiteers and Remainers continues to widen and a General Election looms over Christmas.

The uncertainty, party politics and farcical four Brexit extensions could be comical, if it weren’t responsible for generating great instability at every level of society. Among all the chaos, confusion and the bumping of heads between UK and EU officials, it feels like many voices have been drowned out.

Ultimately, we need a Brexit that does not disenfranchise the British public, and with little to no transparency given on key issues, many feel left in the dark. But more importantly, it is often the concerns of young people that are disregarded. As the inheritors of a post-Brexit Britain, it will fall to the younger generations to deal with the countless list of consequences, felt across the economy, public services, job market, legal system and so on.  So, one cannot help but wonder why young people seem to be excluded from public and political discourse?

We asked Surrey students to share their opinions and concerns regarding Britain’s upcoming split from the EU.

Emma, a final-year Biomedical Sciences student, said the “whole Brexit ordeal” has just felt like a “living nightmare”.

“I disagree with the way Brexit has been handled and how drawn out the process has become. It’s just made me lose faith in British politics … Solid plans and foundations should have been put in place before the vote […] rather than just leaving the public in the dark. I feel like we have no say in anything anymore. I had to stop watching the news, after a while it became depressing”.

Young people are feeling more disillusioned than ever. In September 2018, a report carried out by UK in a Changing Europe found that “more than half of participants felt that they felt their views are not being listened to”, with a further 90% of participants felt that the government “will not be able to deliver a Brexit that will work for future generations”.

 A popular sentiment felt predominately by the young, many who were too young to vote, or have only recently become engaged with politics, is that any democracy worth its salt is allowed to change its mind, especially on an issue as extensive and as complex as Brexit – or at the very least, we should have the opportunity to make a more informed decision and vote again.

What’s more, Brexit is actually damaging to our mental health. A Britain Thinks poll released earlier this year found that 83% of those surveyed were sick of hearing about Brexit, while 64% thought it was damaging their mental health. When asked to describe Brexit, the poll noted a clear deterioration in public opinion: in 2017, it was words such as “confusing” or “uncertain”; now, it is “broken” and “chaos”.

Conor, a second-year Surrey student, had this to say:

“I think it has worsened divides between people – the left and the right, older and younger generations. Overnight two identities were formed, and you had to pick a side. I think it’s created a real rift between people, and the referendum really opened my eyes to how much tension was brewing just under the surface … I don’t see it getting better anytime soon”.

In a time of political stability and uncertainty such as this, it is important to open up dialogue and to come to mutual agreements which are compassionate, humanistic and achievable. Brexit, by nature, is a polarizing subject, but we are not seeing any steps being made to bridge the gap between groups: discourse is often heated and inflammatory, and people are growing tired of headline after headline which look to fearmonger or bewilder.

“Relationships within and between political parties seem to be strained – but looking forward what we need right now is cooperation.”

Sophia, a final-year student from Germany, spoke to me about her concerns as an EU national living in the UK:

“I’ve been studying in the UK since I was 16, and I love British people – but Brexit worries me. Firstly, what will this mean for me staying here? Secondly, will my friends need a visa if they want to visit me in Germany? I also feel like the attitudes surrounding immigrants has changed since Brexit. I’m seeing a lot more hate speech around alone, and I’m concerned that Britain could become a lot more xenophobic.”

A study by the University of Strathclyde into the experiences of Eastern European students across England and Wales found that 77% of pupils had suffered racism, xenophobia or bullying, with nearly half reporting that such behaviour had become more frequent since the referendum.

Many feel that Brexit has somewhat legitimised the xenophobic rhetoric of many right-wing groups, namely UKIP. This was further reinforced by the shift in public discourse surrounding issues such as the EU and immigration.

Practically it seems, regardless of the outcome, Brexit will affect us all. Whilst flights, ferries, trains and any other kind of travel are still guaranteed post-Brexit under international law. It is uncertain what visas may be required and what privileges will be lost; duty free, mobile roaming, health care access, regulations that protect our consumer rights, freedom of movement…

As for EU citizens, it remains equally uncertain, it may be necessary to take out additional visas and healthcare insurance. Those looking to stay in the UK after 30th June 2021 will need to apply before this date to the EU Settlement Scheme get either settled or pre-settled status.

One way or another, Brexit is (probably) happening. This will mean changes, big or small, are on the way. Whilst uncertainty and misinformation sucks… our best defence against Brexit is making sure we keep ourselves informed and updated, and that we make our voices heard – register to vote if you haven’t already!

Text by Declan Purcell (@ardall_)
Photography by Ellie Thompson (@_erthompson)
Videography by Gunjun Bist (@gunjunwanders)
Models: Bojana Simicevic, Leyla Ucar (@leyla_ucarx), Anastasia Koukouraki (@anastasiakouk)
Creative Direction/Production: Natalie Carter (@nat_carts), Amy Parry and Rebecca Cofie (@beccacofie).

The post The Brexit Edit: Youth Opinion appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: A New Insight Into Instagram
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Last month, Instagram removed the ‘Following’ tab with their app update, which had allowed users to see activity from people they follow. Now there are international trials of ‘removing likes’ on posts so that the number of likes that a post has received is no longer displayed to other users. But how will this affect […]

The post A New Insight Into Instagram appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Last month, Instagram removed the ‘Following’ tab with their app update, which had allowed users to see activity from people they follow. Now there are international trials of ‘removing likes’ on posts so that the number of likes that a post has received is no longer displayed to other users. But how will this affect us as users, and the cultural landscape as a whole?

Instagram says that they want to “remove the pressure of how many likes a post receives”, and they seem to genuinely mean it. Undeniably they want their users to have a good experience on the platform, if nothing else to prevent negative press doing the rounds. In 2017, a 14-year-old girl named Molly Russell took her own life after having been influenced by self-harm, depression and suicide communities on Instagram; in the wake of such stories, the pressure rests on the shoulders of Zuckerberg and other social media giants, to show that they are keeping platforms safe for their users.

However, the reality is that Instagram, and its silicon valley siblings, thrive off of us being unhealthily addicted. Since the ad revenue-reliant, attention-captivating platform functions purely from people using it incessantly and compulsively, it’s hard to know how much we can trust their promises.

Director of the Center for Humane Technology, Tristan Harris, revealed this June, at The Aspen Ideas Festival, how social media companies are not just helping us to see things that we like, but are really controlling our ability to make our own independent choices about what we see. It is purpose-built and designed to capture human attention, which they can sell on to advertisers.

From here it becomes clear the level of power and duty of responsibility that Instagram holds. Arguably, echoing scary similarities to the “Big brother state” of Orwell’s 1984….?

Instagram, and its silicon valley siblings, thrive off of us being unhealthily addicted

Impact of Removing the ‘Following’ Tab

The removal follows Instagram who have said not many people were using it or even knew it was there, as well as a desire to major on simplicity and cut out redundant features.

Let’s be honest, it was a bit too stalker-ish in some ways. Sure, we like seeing what our friends are enjoying and interested in, but it often begs the question; Why have I spent the last half an hour browsing who liked what photos and commented on which posts? The majority people and pages that are completely irrelevant to us. Many of us didn’t even know that every late-night like would later surface on friends’ activity tabs.

Besides, since the introduction of the simpler and more personalised ‘Explore’ tab, which allows users to discover content related to who they follow and what they already enjoy seeing, keeping tabs on friends’ interactions with their favourite posts and users just isn’t the most effective way to find content you love anymore.

Consequences for Society?

Perhaps as a result of this more uniquely tailored experience, in effect showing you what you want to see, there are wider social implications. I often find that my Explore tab is brimming with the same kind of accounts, showing the same kind of posts with the same kind of message; but still only a subset of the wider opinion. In seeing more and more of what we value, we see less and less of what society collectively values.

By connecting us with more and more of what we like, and want to see, we become disconnected and isolated from views which challenge and conflict with our worldview. It’s fair to say that these isolated corners of the Internet have been partly responsible for misinformation, which has accommodated the polarisation of politics and the rise of fake news.

A backlash against this feeling of being under the thumb with how we use social media and what we’re exposed to isn’t a new thing either. We’ve all got a friend who has somewhat melodramatically announced (on Instagram) that they’re “QUITTING SOCIAL MEDIA” (just to make their imminent lack of annoying presence quite clear) while some have more mellowly described that they’re, ‘taking a break’ for a bit.

Many users have become aware of the fact that they’re seeing content that isn’t necessarily helpful and resolved to take back control of what they’re being fed on a daily basis by looking to body-positive accounts, celebrities or influencers who offer more realistic depictions of life or leaving the platform altogether.

As for removing the visibility of likes, for many of us, it will feel like a huge relief; yes, we still have that social validation score of the number of people who have liked our post right in front of them, should we choose to check it. But now that this popularity metric isn’t exposed to all, we can be left to process the confidence-boost or the self-esteem blow independently. The hustle and hurry culture of today squeezes out most opportunity for self-reflection and processing; maybe it will be easier to do without the interference of comparison and jealousy.

And yet, amidst heartbreaks such as Molly Russell’s death, the social hierarchies based around the number of likes on posts, and the opinion-reinforcement of social media echo-chambers, there is us: users, now across multiple generations, who want simply to enjoy visual content, grow relationships with friends and share a snapshot of their lives. These and future steps taken by Instagram could make all the difference to that reality.

Text by Barney Venable
Picture research by Anna Irina; featured image from Pinterest.

The post A New Insight Into Instagram appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Upcoming Talent: Pattern
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
Last Friday, Guildford-based band – Pattern – played at the Face Bar in Reading, an alternative music venue loved by locals for its intimate space and display of new talent. The band played some of their singles including: ‘Can’t Sleep’, ‘L.A.T’ and ‘What You Do’, with the crowd enjoying their chilled and groovy vibe. With influences including […]

The post Upcoming Talent: Pattern appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Last Friday, Guildford-based band – Pattern – played at the Face Bar in Reading, an alternative music venue loved by locals for its intimate space and display of new talent. The band played some of their singles including: ‘Can’t Sleep’, ‘L.A.T’ and ‘What You Do’, with the crowd enjoying their chilled and groovy vibe. With influences including icons such as Radiohead and Tom Misch, the band have created a sound that mixes rock, funk and pop with heavenly guitar solos and choruses that will resonate in your head for days on end. When asked how they would describe their sound, the band answered: “We wouldn’t really stick one genre onto our band. We mainly just like to write music that we think sounds cool, whether it be in a similar genre to the last song or something completely different.” 

The band, made up of singer Louis Whitley; guitarists Will Jones and George Fleming; bassist Jack Taylor and Max Colley on drums are all students from ACM in Guildford where they met and started playing together last year. With three songs already on Spotify and another due to come out any day now, the band are well on their way to being successful. Whilst discussing the song writing process, the band said; ‘Usually Will or Jack would start with a cool melody or bass line, and then Max would create a drum groove that works well with it. We usually experiment a lot.’ Coming up with original and meaningful lyrics can often be the most problematic part of writing music, which Pattern confirm; “Making different sections of songs and making sure the previous section works with the new section is the biggest challenge. But sometimes we just jam together and a cool idea or song will just come out of no-where.”  

In their short time together, they have become a real presence in the local music scene, with their talent recognised by BBC Introducing and played on BBC Radio Surrey. They have played venues like The Boileroom supporting Australian band: Planet, The Acoustic Lounge in Bracknell, The Basement in Kingston and The Star Inn, as well as The Tunbridge Wells Forum which they will have played at in October to support punk band Feet.  

Make sure to follow their Instagram: @patternofficial_ for all things Pattern and upcoming gigs.

Text by Daisy Colley
Picture research by Anna Irina; featured image from Pinterest.

The post Upcoming Talent: Pattern appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: Humans of Surrey: A Series by Kobǝ Gutierrez, Season 1
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
“My project is called ‘Humans’ and it focuses identity and personality. I take a portrait photo (using a Canon EOS 5000 film camera with 35mm colour negative film) of a person and they choose the pose and background. I then pose them a “thought-provoking” question, which they can interpret and answer in any way they […]

The post Humans of Surrey: A Series by Kobǝ Gutierrez, Season 1 appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
“My project is called ‘Humans’ and it focuses identity and personality. I take a portrait photo (using a Canon EOS 5000 film camera with 35mm colour negative film) of a person and they choose the pose and background. I then pose them a “thought-provoking” question, which they can interpret and answer in any way they choose. Their photo’s caption will feature both the question and the answer, thus each post respectively will give an insight into the person’s being, way of thinking, and identity.”

“Describe a memory you want to forget but can’t.”

Anna – “My mum and dad fight a lot and rarely speak to each other even till this day. One memory ingrained in my brain for many, many years was a time when I was watching a funny TV show with my mum and dad. Someone on TV made a joke and my mum and dad turned to each other and laughed. I’ve never seen such happy and genuine expressions on their faces, let alone see them look at each other. They didn’t see me look at them but those were, to me, the most precious 5 seconds – but also the 5 seconds that I wish I never saw.”

“If you could speak to yourself from 5 years ago, what would you say?”

Liangyi – “Don’t listen to yourself.”

“Tell me about a time when you felt like you’d lost it all.”

Chin – “Honestly, there hasn’t been a time in my life yet where I truly felt like I lost it all, but there have been moments that I felt lost. My last relationship challenged me and made me question my worth. I saw the signs from the start but refused to confront it. Lol love and infatuation really blind you man. I ended up getting hurt. I’ve always been positive and hopeful no matter how bad situations get but I became the opposite for a while. I only focused on that one ‘bad’ thing and temporarily, well, lost my queen ass self. Then I realised we often forget that how we feel is determined by how we think about ourselves. We are what we repeatedly do. We either make ourselves miserable or we make ourselves strong; the amount of work is the same. I started to appreciate the little things in life that many of us take for granted like the chance to wake up every day to restart. I wanted to be in control of my emotions rather than a person or a situation. I learnt many things along the way like the importance of unconditional love towards family, friends, and especially to the person who cracked my cute lil heart. Love is never wrong. When someone comes into your life who allows you the opportunity to experience love, that’s always a true gift. That romantic love has evolved into a love that encompasses care and compassion for a person who had an important place in my life. That became the main recipe of my healing process. I just wanted to grow. You really can’t move forward unless you forgive yourself and the situation. Also, trust your intuition lol. In some ways, I am thankful for that relationship because it held a mirror in front of me to really see who I am, my worth, and what I deserve. They say, ‘When the pain is over, the remembrance of it often becomes a pleasure’ – and so it is! I’m so excited for what the future has in store for me. I’ve so much love to give and to spread. With that said, even the moments you feel like you’ve lost it all can pave a way for you to discover more about yourself and make you stronger; just trust the process.”

“Tell me something you wish you didn’t do but did anyway.”

Kamara – “There are too many. I think there are a lot of things I did that apply to this, all of which seemed like such a big thing at the time, but now looking back, it’s actually not that deep lol. It’s inevitable for us to make mistakes and regret them like hell later on but we learn from them. I used to dwell and overthink about so many things in the past that I felt were impossible to overcome. It’s different now. No doubt it’s still a challenge, since failure doesn’t particularly feel like a learning opportunity hah. But yeah I don’t know, aren’t ‘mistakes’ just experiences? You get me?”

“Tell me about the biggest fight you have been in.”

Phil – “I’ve had many fights, almost all of them physical; arguments with exes, squaring up with my brothers, and even some friends just to name a few. But honestly, if I look at this question and ask what fight I have struggled with the most, and one that still affects me to this day and probably will continue to till the end of my days, I would have to say the fight I’ve had with depression. It sounds cliché as fuck, I know, but that shit gets to you. It’s like you’re in a maze with the exact route of how to escape, but the closer you get to the exit, the more blind you become, and you somehow end up at the start again and it’s just a cycle of that constantly. Yeah. If that makes sense haha. That’s my biggest fight. Pizza helps though.”

“What’s the hardest decision you’ve had to make?”

Adrien – “Letting her go.”

Humans: Duality – “Describe someone you hate.”

Mack – “They’re really biased towards my sister and I hate that. I feel like I never really spent that much time with them as they were busy with my sister. I kinda can’t blame them though. My sister went through some tough shit, so I guess someone had to be there for her. But when I went through some tough shit, they would be like ‘suck it up’. I mean, I got why they said that and stuff, but I kinda just wanted someone to give me attention like they did for my sister. I now resent my sister because of it too. There are other stories, but I think I would be giving away who this person is. If it isn’t already obvious. Haha. Boom.”

Humans: Duality – “Describe the saddest you’ve ever been.”

Jess -“I am washing my hands
it goes down the pipe and sink
under water I watch my words
drain away from me I can
see her tired eyes I can
hear their told you so I can
feel hands around my lungs
tearing leering fearing
the hands are still mine”

Interviews and photoshoots conducted by Kobǝ Gutierrez

Special thanks to Kobǝ for this collaborative feature.

The post Humans of Surrey: A Series by Kobǝ Gutierrez, Season 1 appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.

item.title: SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY
item.dc:creator: SUBCULTURED
item.description:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the […]

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
There are few items in the student wardrobe that can claim they have seen said student through everything, from running around campus during the day to the early morning hours looking for food after a good night out. Jeans would definitely be included in that list. And so the mission is simple: the cooler the pair of jeans is, the more versatile the styling. Add to that good quality, and you truly have an item that can see you through every hour of your busy student life.

Cheap Monday zeroed in on the importance of good denim and has made a huge mark in the fashion market with its line: clothes that are comfortable, whether loose-fitting or figure-hugging, with an original design that makes a statement effortlessly. Whether it is a pop of neon orange in an all-black outfit, a skull necklace or a logo-bearing pair of jeans, the result is the same: a look that combines functional urban cool – in other words, comfort with a bit of an edge and lots of attitude. Against the backdrop of busy London, with its graffitied alleyways and iconic buildings, the clothes stand out among the crowds due to their vibrant, rebellious feel.

I suppose, then, there is only one thing left to say: thank God, it’s… (Cheap) Monday.

 Orange Jumper – Tap Echologo Knit

Black Sweater – Worth Droop Logo Sweat

Women’s Ripped Jeans – Dona Slash Black Mom Jeans

Men’s Orange Hoodie – Scope Fleece Hood

Orange T-shirt – Screen Tiny Skull Tee

Red Coat – Agent Bomber

Women’s Jeans with Side Panelling – Sound 36 Black Tape Jeans

Grey Beanie – Skull Beanie

Quilted Jacket – Crypto Puffer Vest

Men’s Jeans – Tight Horror Skinny Jeans

Women’s Fleece Jacket – Function Fleece Jacket

Denim Jacket – Legit Denim Jacket

 

A peek at the behind-the-scenes of the shoot:

 

Creative direction by Rebecca Cofie, Setareh Sanjarani and Natalie Carter

Photography by Leeya Mirza

Videography by Ana Maria

Editorial by Alice Papadopoulou

Models: Kyle Birkitt, Mack McCarroll, Talia Cherkez & Silia Marianou

Special thanks to Cheap Monday for collaborating with us.

The post SUBCULTURED X CHEAP MONDAY appeared first on SUBCULTURED Magazine.
